title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: clmstan R package fitting Cumulative Link Models (CLMs) using Bayesian inference via CmdStan. provides: - 11 link functions: 5 standard + 6 flexible parametric links - 3 threshold structures: flexible, equidistant, symmetric - Bayesian estimation: Full posterior inference MCMC - Pre-compiled Stan models: Fast execution via instantiate package

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: using clmstan, need install CmdStan:
code: # Step 1: Install cmdstanr install.packages("cmdstanr",                  repos = c("https://stan-dev.r-universe.dev",                            getOption("repos")))  # Step 2: Install CmdStan (only needed once) library(cmdstanr) install_cmdstan()  # Step 3: Install clmstan # devtools::install_github("t-momozaki/clmstan")

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: Fit cumulative link model just lines: wine dataset contains ratings (1-5) 72 wine samples two predictors: temperature (cold/warm) contact (yes/).
code: library(clmstan) library(ordinal) data(wine)  # Fit a model with logit link fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine,                 chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  # View results print(fit) summary(fit)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: â€™re familiar ordinal package, transition clmstan straightforward:

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: library(ordinal) library(clmstan) data(wine)  # ordinal::clm (frequentist) fit_freq <- clm(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine, link = "logit")  # clmstan::clm_stan (Bayesian) fit_bayes <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine, link = "logit",                       chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  # Compare coefficients coef(fit_freq) coef(fit_bayes)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: Posterior distributions: clmstan provides full posterior samples, enabling Bayesian inference (credible intervals, posterior predictive checks) Reproducibility: Set set.seed() clm_stan() reproducible results Computation time: MCMC sampling slower MLE, provides richer inference

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: clmstan supports 11 link functions, CLM package.

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: # View available link functions supported_links("standard")  # Logit (default) - proportional odds model fit_logit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "logit",                       chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Probit - normal distribution fit_probit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "probit",                        chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Complementary log-log - asymmetric (right-skewed) fit_cloglog <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "cloglog",                         chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Log-log - asymmetric (left-skewed) fit_loglog <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "loglog",                        chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Cauchit - heavy tails fit_cauchit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "cauchit",                         chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: Flexible links parameters can fixed estimated. theoretical background, see Wang & Dey (2011) GEV, Jiang & Dey (2015) SP, Naranjo et al.Â (2015) AEP.
code: # View flexible link functions supported_links("flexible")  # t-link with fixed df (heavier tails than logit) fit_t8 <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "tlink",                    link_param = list(df = 8),                    chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # t-link with estimated df (data-driven tail behavior) fit_t_est <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "tlink",                       link_param = list(df = "estimate"),                       chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # GEV link with estimated shape parameter fit_gev <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "gev",                     link_param = list(xi = "estimate"),                     chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Aranda-Ordaz link (asymmetric) fit_ao <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "aranda_ordaz",                    link_param = list(lambda = "estimate"),                    chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Symmetric Power link (skewness adjustment) fit_sp <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "sp",                    base = "logit",                    link_param = list(r = "estimate"),                    chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Log-gamma link fit_lg <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "log_gamma",                    link_param = list(lambda = "estimate"),                    chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # AEP link (asymmetric exponential power) fit_aep <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "aep",                     link_param = list(theta1 = "estimate", theta2 = "estimate"),                     chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: clmstan supports three threshold parameterizations:

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: threshold freely estimated (K-1 parameters K categories):
code: fit_flex <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, threshold = "flexible",                      chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: Thresholds equally spaced (2 parameters: start + interval):
code: # Useful for Likert scales with assumed equal intervals fit_equi <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, threshold = "equidistant",                      chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: Thresholds symmetric around zero (useful scales neutral center):
code: fit_sym <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, threshold = "symmetric",                     chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: clmstan uses weakly informative default priors, can customize .

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: prior() function provides brms-like interface:
code: # Single prior fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 prior = prior(normal(0, 1), class = "b"),                 chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Multiple priors fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 prior = c(                   prior(normal(0, 1), class = "b"),                   prior(normal(0, 5), class = "Intercept")                 ),                 chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)  # Prior for link parameters fit_gev <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "gev",                     link_param = list(xi = "estimate"),                     prior = prior(normal(0, 0.5), class = "xi"),                     chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: normal(mu, sigma)      # Normal distribution gamma(alpha, beta)     # Gamma distribution (shape, rate) student_t(df, mu, sigma)  # Student-t distribution cauchy(mu, sigma)      # Cauchy distribution flat()                 # Flat (improper) prior

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: backward compatibility:
code: fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 prior = clm_prior(beta_sd = 1, c_sd = 5),                 chains = 2, iter = 1000, warmup = 500)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine,                 chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  # Quick overview print(fit)  # Detailed summary with credible intervals summary(fit) summary(fit, probs = c(0.025, 0.5, 0.975))  # Extract point estimates coef(fit)                    # Posterior mean (default) coef(fit, type = "median")   # Posterior median

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: # Trace plots (check mixing) plot(fit, type = "trace")  # Posterior density plot(fit, type = "dens")  # Posterior intervals plot(fit, type = "intervals")  # Autocorrelation (check for high autocorrelation) plot(fit, type = "acf")  # Select specific parameters plot(fit, type = "trace", pars = c("beta[1]", "beta[2]"))

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: Key diagnostics check: - Rhat: < 1.01 (values > 1.01 indicate poor convergence) - ESS (bulk/tail): > 400 (low values suggest inefficient sampling) - Divergences: 0 (divergences indicate sampling problems)
code: # Quick summary diagnostics(fit)  # Detailed output diagnostics(fit, detail = TRUE)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine,                 chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  # Predict most likely category pred_class <- predict(fit, type = "class") head(pred_class)  # Prediction for new data newdata <- data.frame(   temp = factor("warm", levels = levels(wine$temp)),   contact = factor("yes", levels = levels(wine$contact)) ) predict(fit, newdata = newdata, type = "class")

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: # Predicted probabilities for each category pred_probs <- predict(fit, type = "probs") head(pred_probs)  # Alternative: fitted values fitted_vals <- fitted(fit) head(fitted_vals)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: # Draw from posterior predictive distribution y_rep <- posterior_predict(fit) dim(y_rep)  # draws x observations  # Uncertainty in predictions pred_draws <- predict(fit, type = "class", summary = FALSE)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: Use LOO-CV (Leave-One-Cross-Validation) model comparison: Interpreting LOO results: - Lower elpd_loo (expected log pointwise predictive density) indicates better fit - Pareto k values > 0.7 suggest unreliable LOO estimates observations
code: # Fit competing models fit1 <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "logit",                  chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000) fit2 <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine, link = "logit",                  chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000) fit3 <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine, link = "probit",                  chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  # Compute LOO-CV loo1 <- loo(fit1) loo2 <- loo(fit2) loo3 <- loo(fit3)  # View results print(loo1)  # Pareto k diagnostic plot plot(loo1)  # Compare models loo::loo_compare(loo1, loo2, loo3)  # WAIC is also available waic(fit1)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: â€™s recommended workflow ordinal data analysis:
code: library(clmstan) library(ordinal) data(wine)  # Step 1: Fit baseline model set.seed(123) fit_base <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine,                      link = "logit", threshold = "flexible",                      chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  # Step 2: Check convergence diagnostics(fit_base) plot(fit_base, type = "trace")  # Step 3: Review results summary(fit_base)  # Step 4: Try alternative link functions fit_probit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine,                        link = "probit",                        chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  fit_gev <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp + contact, data = wine,                     link = "gev", link_param = list(xi = "estimate"),                     chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  # Step 5: Compare models loo_base <- loo(fit_base) loo_probit <- loo(fit_probit) loo_gev <- loo(fit_gev) loo::loo_compare(loo_base, loo_probit, loo_gev)  # Step 6: Final model interpretation summary(fit_base) plot(fit_base, type = "intervals")

title: Getting Started with clmstan
code: # Check CmdStan installation cmdstanr::cmdstan_path() cmdstanr::cmdstan_version()  # If not found, install CmdStan: cmdstanr::install_cmdstan()

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: see Rhat > 1.01 low ESS:
code: # Increase iterations and warmup fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 chains = 4,                 iter = 4000,                 warmup = 2000)  # Increase adapt_delta (helps with divergences) fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 chains = 4,                 iter = 2000,                 warmup = 1000,                 adapt_delta = 0.95)  # Increase max_treedepth fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 chains = 4,                 iter = 2000,                 warmup = 1000,                 max_treedepth = 12)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: Divergent transitions indicate sampler difficulty exploring posterior: Increase adapt_delta: Try 0.95, 0.99, even 0.999 Reparameterize: Try different threshold structures Simplify priors: Use informative priors Check data: Look separation outliers
code: # High adapt_delta fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 chains = 4,                 iter = 2000,                 warmup = 1000,                 adapt_delta = 0.99)

title: Getting Started with clmstan
text: large datasets:
code: # Reduce number of chains fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 chains = 2,                 iter = 2000,                 warmup = 1000)  # Run chains in parallel (default) fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine,                 chains = 4,                 parallel_chains = 4)

title: Link Functions in clmstan
text: cumulative distribution function (CDF) determines probabilities mapped latent scale. Different CDFs produce different model behavior, especially extreme categories.

title: Link Functions in clmstan
text: Key observations: logit probit: Nearly identical symmetric curves cloglog: Right-skewed (slower approach 1) loglog: Left-skewed (slower approach 0) cauchit: Heavy tails (slower approach 0 1)
code: x <- seq(-4, 4, length.out = 200)  cdfs <- data.frame(   x = x,   logit = plogis(x),   probit = pnorm(x),   cloglog = 1 - exp(-exp(x)),   loglog = exp(-exp(-x)),   cauchit = pcauchy(x) )  par(mar = c(4, 4, 2, 1)) plot(x, cdfs$logit, type = "l", lwd = 2, col = 1,      xlab = "x", ylab = "F(x)", main = "Standard Link CDFs",      ylim = c(0, 1)) lines(x, cdfs$probit, lwd = 2, col = 2) lines(x, cdfs$cloglog, lwd = 2, col = 3) lines(x, cdfs$loglog, lwd = 2, col = 4) lines(x, cdfs$cauchit, lwd = 2, col = 5, lty = 2) legend("bottomright",        legend = c("logit", "probit", "cloglog", "loglog", "cauchit"),        col = 1:5, lwd = 2, lty = c(1, 1, 1, 1, 2)) abline(h = 0.5, lty = 3, col = "gray")

title: Link Functions in clmstan
text: t-link interpolates cauchit (df=1\text{df}=1) probit (dfâ†’âˆž\text{df} \\infty):  Guidelines df:
code: x <- seq(-4, 4, length.out = 200)  par(mar = c(4, 4, 2, 1)) plot(x, pnorm(x), type = "l", lwd = 2, col = "black", lty = 2,      xlab = "x", ylab = "F(x)", main = "t-link CDFs (varying df)",      ylim = c(0, 1)) lines(x, pt(x, df = 1), lwd = 2, col = 2) lines(x, pt(x, df = 2), lwd = 2, col = 3) lines(x, pt(x, df = 3), lwd = 2, col = 4) lines(x, pt(x, df = 4), lwd = 2, col = 5) lines(x, pt(x, df = 8), lwd = 2, col = 6) lines(x, pt(x, df = 30), lwd = 2, col = 7) legend("bottomright",        legend = c("probit (df=Inf)", "df=1 (Cauchy)", "df=2", "df=3",                   "df=4", "df=8", "df=30"),        col = c(1, 2:7), lwd = 2, lty = c(2, rep(1, 6))) abline(h = 0.5, lty = 3, col = "gray")

title: Link Functions in clmstan
text: Aranda-Ordaz: Î»=1\lambda = 1: Equivalent logit Î»â†’0\lambda \0: Approaches cloglog Useful testing proportional odds assumption GEV (Generalized Extreme Value): Î¾=0\xi = 0: Gumbel type (equivalent loglog) Î¾>0\xi > 0: FrÃ©chet type (heavy upper tail) Î¾<0\xi < 0: Weibull type (bounded upper tail) SP (Symmetric Power): r=1r = 1: Base distribution (e.g., logit) r<1r < 1: Positively skewed r>1r > 1: Negatively skewed Log-Gamma: Î»=0\lambda = 0: Equivalent probit Î»>0\lambda > 0: Heavier right tail Î»<0\lambda < 0: Heavier left tail AEP (Asymmetric Exponential Power): Î¸1,Î¸2>0\theta_1, \theta_2 > 0: Shape parameters controlling left right tails Î¸1=Î¸2=2\theta_1 = \theta_2 = 2: Similar probit (normal-like) Î¸1=Î¸2=1\theta_1 = \theta_2 = 1: Laplace-like (heavier tails) Î¸1â‰ Î¸2\theta_1 \neq \theta_2: Asymmetric tails

title: Link Functions in clmstan
text: use leave-one-cross-validation (LOO-CV) compare predictive performance across 11 models: interpret: Models sorted expected log predictive density (best first) elpd_diff: Difference best model (0 = best) se_diff: Standard error difference Rule thumb: |ðšŽðš•ðš™ðš_ðšðš’ðšðš|<2Ã—ðšœðšŽ_ðšðš’ðšðš|\texttt{elpd\_diff}| < 2 \times \texttt{se\_diff}, difference significant Note: WAIC (Widely Applicable Information Criterion) also available via waic(fit). LOO-CV generally preferred provides diagnostics problematic observations (Pareto k values).
code: # Compute LOO for standard links loo_logit <- loo(fit_logit) loo_probit <- loo(fit_probit) loo_cloglog <- loo(fit_cloglog) loo_loglog <- loo(fit_loglog) loo_cauchit <- loo(fit_cauchit)  # Compute LOO for flexible links loo_tlink <- loo(fit_tlink) loo_aranda <- loo(fit_aranda) loo_gev <- loo(fit_gev) loo_sp <- loo(fit_sp) loo_loggamma <- loo(fit_loggamma) loo_aep <- loo(fit_aep) # Compare all 11 link functions (sorted by expected log predictive density) loo_list <- list(   logit = loo_logit,   probit = loo_probit,   cloglog = loo_cloglog,   loglog = loo_loglog,   cauchit = loo_cauchit,   tlink = loo_tlink,   aranda_ordaz = loo_aranda,   gev = loo_gev,   sp = loo_sp,   log_gamma = loo_loggamma,   aep = loo_aep ) loo::loo_compare(loo_list) #>              elpd_diff se_diff #> probit        0.0       0.0    #> tlink        -0.5       0.4    #> logit        -0.6       0.5    #> gev          -0.9       0.4    #> cloglog      -1.0       1.6    #> sp           -1.3       0.6    #> aranda_ordaz -1.3       0.5    #> loglog       -2.3       1.8    #> log_gamma    -4.8       1.0    #> aep          -5.6       1.7    #> cauchit      -7.6       2.7

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
text: clmstan fits cumulative link models (CLMs) ordinal categorical data using CmdStanR. supports 11 link functions including standard links (logit, probit, cloglog) flexible parametric links (GEV, AEP, Symmetric Power). Models pre-compiled using instantiate package fast execution without runtime compilation.

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
text: Full documentation available : https://t-momozaki.github.io/clmstan/

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
text: package requires: CmdStan - Stanâ€™s command-line interface cmdstanr - R interface CmdStan (CRAN)

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
code: # Install cmdstanr from r-universe (recommended) install.packages("cmdstanr",                  repos = c("https://stan-dev.r-universe.dev",                            getOption("repos")))

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
text: Note: package installation, Stan models compiled automatically. may take minutes first install.
code: # From CRAN (when available) install.packages("clmstan")  # From GitHub (development version) # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("t-momozaki/clmstan")

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
code: library(clmstan)  # Example data set.seed(123) n <- 100 x <- rnorm(n) latent <- 1.0 * x + rlogis(n) y <- cut(latent, breaks = c(-Inf, -1, 0, 1, Inf), labels = 1:4) data <- data.frame(y = y, x = x)  # Fit a cumulative link model with logit link fit <- clm_stan(y ~ x, data = data, link = "logit",                 chains = 4, iter = 2000, warmup = 1000)  # View results fit$fit$summary(variables = c("beta", "c_transformed", "beta0"))

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
code: # Fixed parameter fit_t <- clm_stan(y ~ x, data = data, link = "tlink",                   link_param = list(df = 8))  # Estimate parameter with Bayesian inference fit_gev <- clm_stan(y ~ x, data = data, link = "gev",                     link_param = list(xi = "estimate"))

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
code: # Equidistant thresholds fit_equi <- clm_stan(y ~ x, data = data, threshold = "equidistant")

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
text: clmstan uses weakly informative default priors: link parameters estimated via Bayesian inference:

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
text: Use prior() function distribution helpers:
code: # Tighter prior on regression coefficients fit <- clm_stan(y ~ x, data = data,                 prior = prior(normal(0, 1), class = "b"))  # Multiple priors fit <- clm_stan(y ~ x, data = data,                 prior = c(                   prior(normal(0, 1), class = "b"),                   prior(normal(0, 5), class = "Intercept")                 ))

title: Cumulative Link Models with CmdStanR
text: estimating link parameters, can specify custom priors:
code: # Custom prior for t-link df parameter fit <- clm_stan(y ~ x, data = data, link = "tlink",                 link_param = list(df = "estimate"),                 prior = prior(gamma(3, 0.2), class = "df"))  # Custom prior for GEV xi parameter fit <- clm_stan(y ~ x, data = data, link = "gev",                 link_param = list(xi = "estimate"),                 prior = prior(normal(0, 0.5), class = "xi"))

title: Asymmetric Exponential Power (AEP) link CDF â€” aep_cdf
Asymmetric Exponential Power (AEP) link CDF â€” aep_cdf
text: x Numeric vector theta1 Left tail parameter (theta1 > 0) theta2 Right tail parameter (theta2 > 0)

title: Asymmetric Exponential Power (AEP) link CDF â€” aep_cdf

title: Asymmetric Exponential Power (AEP) link CDF â€” aep_cdf
text: x <= 0: F(x) = 0.5 * (1 - P(1/theta1, u1)) u1 = (|x| * 2 * Gamma(1 + 1/theta1))^theta1 x > 0: F(x) = 0.5 + 0.5 * P(1/theta2, u2) u2 = (x * 2 * Gamma(1 + 1/theta2))^theta2 P(, x) regularized incomplete gamma function (pgamma). Special case: theta1 = theta2 gives symmetric distribution. Note: theta = 2 Gaussian kernel equal probit due scaling. Reference: Naranjo et al. (2015) Statistics Computing

Default: 0 lambda_lg_sd Normal SD log_gamma lambda. Default: 1 xi_mu Normal mean GEV xi. Default: 0 xi_sd Normal SD GEV xi. Default: 2 r_alpha Gamma shape SP r. Default: 0.5 r_beta Gamma rate SP r. Default: 0.5 theta1_alpha Gamma shape AEP theta1. Default: 2 theta1_beta Gamma rate AEP theta1. Default: 1 theta2_alpha Gamma shape AEP theta2. Default: 2 theta2_beta Gamma rate AEP theta2. title: Available Link Functions â€” link_functions
text: clmstan supports following link functions cumulative link models: Standard links (additional parameters): "logit" - Logistic (proportional odds model) "probit" - Normal (latent variable interpretation) "cloglog" - Complementary log-log (proportional hazards) "loglog" - Log-log (Gumbel minimum) "cauchit" - Cauchy (heavy tails) Flexible links (additional parameters): "tlink" - Student-t (df > 0) df = Inf: equals probit df < 3: increasingly heavy tails; df > 30 nearly normal "aranda_ordaz" - Aranda-Ordaz asymmetric (lambda > 0) lambda = 1: equals logit lambda -> 0: approaches cloglog "gev" - Generalized extreme value (shape parameter xi) xi = 0: Gumbel (equals loglog) xi < 0: Weibull (short tail) xi > 0: Frechet (heavy tail) "sp" - Symmetric power (r > 0, base distribution) r = 1: equals base distribution 0 < r < 1: positively skewed r > 1: negatively skewed "log_gamma" - Log-gamma (lambda) lambda = 0: equals probit lambda > 0 < 0: asymmetric "aep" - Asymmetric exponential power (theta1 > 0, theta2 > 0) alpha = 0.5 fixed identifiability theta1 = theta2: symmetric distribution theta = 2: Gaussian kernel (equal probit due scaling) theta < 2: heavy tails (leptokurtic) theta > 2: light tails (platykurtic)

title: Available Link Functions â€” link_functions
text: Flexible link parameters can either fixed estimated (inferred). Fixed parameters: Specify numeric value   Estimated parameters: Use "estimate" (default prior)   Custom priors: Combine "estimate" prior argument
code: clm_stan(y ~ x, link = "tlink", link_param = list(df = 8)) clm_stan(y ~ x, link = "gev", link_param = list(xi = 0))  # equals loglog clm_stan(y ~ x, link = "aep", link_param = list(theta1 = 2, theta2 = 2))  # symmetric clm_stan(y ~ x, link = "tlink", link_param = list(df = "estimate")) clm_stan(y ~ x, link = "gev", link_param = list(xi = "estimate")) clm_stan(y ~ x, link = "gev",          link_param = list(xi = "estimate"),          prior = prior(normal(0, 0.3), class = "xi"))

title: Available Link Functions â€” link_functions
text: using "estimate", following default priors used:

title: Available Link Functions â€” link_functions
text: Symmetric Power link uses symmetric base distribution F_0, specified via base argument. Supported bases: base = "logit": Logistic base (default) base = "probit": Normal base base = "cauchit": Cauchy base base = "tlink": Student-t base (requires df) Note: Li et al. (2019) define F_0 CDF "whose corresponding PDF symmetric 0".

title: Log-gamma link CDF â€” loggamma_cdf
text: Based log-gamma distribution: lambda = 0: probit (normal) lambda > 0: F(x) = pgamma(exp(x), shape = lambda, rate = lambda) lambda < 0: F(x) = 1 - pgamma(exp(-x), shape = -lambda, rate = -lambda)

title: Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation for clmstan objects â€” loo.clmstan
text: Computes approximate leave-one-cross-validation (LOO-CV) fitted cumulative link model using Pareto smoothed importance sampling (PSIS).

title: Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation for clmstan objects â€” loo.clmstan
code: # S3 method for class 'clmstan' loo(x, ..., r_eff = NULL, cores = getOption("mc.cores", 1), save_psis = FALSE)

title: Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation for clmstan objects â€” loo.clmstan
text: x clmstan object returned clm_stan. ... Additional arguments passed loo. r_eff vector relative effective sample sizes observation, NULL (default) compute automatically using relative_eff. Set NA skip r_eff computation (faster diagnostics may -optimistic). cores number cores use parallel computation. Defaults getOption("mc.cores", 1). save_psis TRUE, PSIS object saved returned object. required downstream functions like E_loo(). Default FALSE.

title: Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation for clmstan objects â€” loo.clmstan
text: object class c("psis_loo", "loo") containing: estimates: matrix columns Estimate SE elpd_loo, p_loo, looic. pointwise: matrix pointwise contributions. diagnostics: list Pareto k values effective sample sizes observation.

title: Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation for clmstan objects â€” loo.clmstan
text: function extracts log-likelihood matrix (log_lik) computed generated quantities block Stan model passes loo. Pareto k diagnostics: Observations high Pareto k values (k > 0.7) indicate potential problems LOO approximation observations. Use plot() returned object visualize Pareto k values. Model comparison: Use loo_compare compare multiple models. Models higher elpd_loo preferred.

title: Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation for clmstan objects â€” loo.clmstan
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ fit <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine) loo_result <- loo(fit) print(loo_result) plot(loo_result)  # Compare two models fit1 <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "logit") fit2 <- clm_stan(rating ~ temp, data = wine, link = "probit") loo::loo_compare(loo(fit1), loo(fit2)) } # }

Valid classes : "b": Regression coefficients (beta) "Intercept": Cutpoints/thresholds (flexible) "c1": First cutpoint (equidistant) "d": Threshold interval (equidistant) "cpos": Positive cutpoints (symmetric) "df": Degrees freedom (tlink) "lambda_ao": Lambda parameter (aranda_ordaz) "lambda_lg": Lambda parameter (log_gamma) "xi": Xi parameter (gev) "r": R parameter (sp) "theta1", "theta2": Theta parameters (aep) coef Optional coefficient name (future extension).
